sections.title: Module 4 Strategy
sections.text:
4H. Module 4 Strategy (Geoff Speare)
Module 4 Exodus adds one new feature (contracts) for all games, and 2 another sets (augmentations & spaceborns) for longer games. Contract opportunism is important as you go about your industrialization and Futures building.
It’s exciting to explore the new stuff, but don’t forget that contracts should not be undertaken unless they help achieve your core mission. Keep your (steely) eyes on the ball!

sections.title: Contract Tips
sections.text:
4H1. Contract Tips (4-Cycle Game)
Contracts can jump start your economy and missions, but can turn into distractions without proper planning:
ACHIEVEMENT TABLE [4G4]
EASILY MISSED: The Ideology present at a given time influences the VP count for the board meeting but seniority disks are only considered at the endgame. [4G3]
MODULE 4 - EXODUS | HIGH FRONTIER 4 ALL | 37 a. Early Rockets. Boosting quickly allows nabbing the easy Glory chits, which makes paleoconservative directive (O5b) extremely attractive. Module 4 adds new advantages to early missions. If you are the first with an Operational rocket, you will have an edge in bidding for and fulfilling contracts, providing funding, VP, and Abilities. Players without early rockets may try to influence politics to keep those contracts unavailable.
b. Timing. As contracts need to be boosted, it’s best to take a contract when you have something else to boost: your initial rocket, an improved component, etc. The number of Operations you can perform in a game is limited, so do as much as you can with each one!
c. Hazards. When bidding on (and fulfilling) a contract, all of the concerns for any High Frontier mission apply: radiation hardness, Mass, Burns, Hazards, and landing/liftoff. In particular, don’t forget that the contract has its own Mass and rad hardness! If a contract with the "Humans on Board" icon suffers involuntary
Decommission, you suffer severe default penalties (4B6) along with the loss of equipment.
d. Turn Order. Players after you in turn order have an advantage; they effectively get an extra turn to complete the contract. If these players are likely to bid, make sure you have a useful second operation planned if you do not win the contract auction. If they do win, starting another auction next turn is often a good idea - unless they complete their contract very quickly, they will be unable to bid.
e. Bait. Contract auctions are also great opportunities to encourage opponents to make a mistake, or to nudge them away from your mission goals. Tempting an opponent with the right contract may distract them from some other goal they should be pursuing - or even cause them to bid too aggressively and default. The price of acquiring the wrong contract is much higher than that of buying the wrong patent. Think carefully when you bid.
f. The Best Contracts. Contracts are central to Module 4. What makes one contract better than others? • Going My Way. The best contracts are those that have low opportunity cost because you were planning to go in that area anyway. “Return” contracts are often easier to take in the early game because you’ll probably be returning to LEO anyway. Later in the game, contracts must be judged in terms of return on investment:
what else could you be doing?
• Abilities. Important in the early game. Bailout saves you 3 Aqua - or a critical card - each time budget cuts occurs. Insight (cycle a deck before a research auction) helps get the cards you need and/or buries cards your opponents want. Other Abilities (such as on contracts involving Mercury) may change your plans entirely.
TIP: The contracts with a subsurface ocean destination are common, making
Ceres a common early destination. If your own goals include Ceres, watch the contract market and the politics to acquire such contracts, or keep them out of enemy hands. [4He]
• Aqua Advance. Important especially as the game progresses. Watch for contracts that match what your opponents are doing and keep the Active Law away from them.
• Victory Points (VP). Contracts are worth Victory Points - but usually, building Factories and Colonies is worth more. If you who pursue nothing but contracts, it is unlikely that you will win. Instead, try to leverage contracts to accelerate your industrialization efforts without letting them distract you from that goal.

sections.title: Planning Tips
sections.text:
4H2. Planning Tips (Modules 1 + 2 + 4 Games) a. Goals. A Module 4 game has 3 extra steps that you may need to get into an advantageous endgame position:
• Fulfill Contracts. (Module 4). Enough to gain 4-5 icons, including at least one of each type and no more than 2 of each type.
• Get Factories. (VP, ET Produce)
• Get Bernals. (VP, Aqua; VP and operations through Colonists)
• Augment Colonists. (Module 4)
• Transport Augmented Colonists to Promotion Locations (Module 4)
• Get TW Thruster. (movement)
• Get Futures. (VP) b. Long-Range Planning. Your Turns are often either Operation-limited or movement-limited. Try to combine both in a Turn, for instance ET producing cards while moving a contract to its destination.
• Operations. Contracts require Operations to acquire and boost (as with patents, it’s better for you to win an auction that someone else started, to save yourself an operation), but give you Aqua - which in effect saves you Operations that you would have otherwise spent selling cards or fundraising.
• Movement. Fulfilling contracts requires a lot more rocket movement. The more you can align that movement with other missions (industrializing, moving Bernals, etc.), or perform it when you are operationlimited (such as while you are ET Producing, or buying cards to launch a Bernal), the faster your game will progress.
c. Contract Variety. With the contract icon requirements for augmentation (and thus for Promotions), choosing a variety of contracts is much more important than in Core+M0 games. Fortunately, there are multiple valid paths. Getting an early start on contract diversity can be quite useful. The Political Assembly can fill up quickly, making it harder to move the Active Law. If you can fulfill contracts before the Active
EASILY MISSED: A contract with a heavy mass eats profits with a heavy boost cost, and greatly complicates landing and liftoff. [4H1f]
Law gets stuck, or before the isobank, you are one step ahead. Alternatively, waiting for (or causing) the construction of the isobank leads to contracts which are harder to fulfill, but which have more icons.
d. To Bernal or Not To Bernal. One of the nice things about High Frontier 4 is the balance between “Bernal first” and “Factory first” strategies. Both are reasonable - and often, doing the one fewer people have chosen is the best option. Everyone needs a Bernal (probably a Home Bernal), and everyone needs Factories, but which has primacy is opportunistic. Module 4 changes this balance a bit:
• Early Bernal. If you focus on an early Bernal, you gain an early Colonist, and early Bernal profits which can be used while you launch your Factory mission. Since a Bernal is needed for the implant operation, you can pick and choose the right augmentations as they appear to augment your Colonists.
• Early Elevator Bernal. Anchoring one of the two elevator Bernals (GEO Elevator or Lofstrom Loop) are tremendously helpful with contracts, as you can boost directly to Bernal with no cost increase. Don’t forget that Module 4 adds an Epic Hazard Roll when Anchoring these in home orbits!
• Early Rocket. Since you need a Spacecraft to complete a contract, an early Rocket leads to early contracts and their advantages (see 4H1a). You can also establish an early Colony in space (i.e. not a Home Bernal), which is necessary for drawing from the new spaceborn Colonist deck and implanting augmentations.

sections.text:
4H3. Augmentation Tips
Augmentation chits don’t go away unless Colonist is Decommissioned, so think about when you put them on.
a. Parenthood is very valuable, especially if everyone goes spaceborn.
b. Pulse Generator & ISRU 1 Buggy address common gaps.
c. Shielding & Jars are more situational but can be very useful.

sections.title: Earthborn vs. Spaceborn
sections.text:
4H4. Earthborn vs. Spaceborn
The more people on a side, the more churn (and the less control).
a. Earthborn Advantages. Parenthood, more isotope multipliers, more miners and engineers, better Futures VP.
b. Spaceborn Advantages. Get Robots, lower average Mass, more Industrialists and prospectors.
